title: The new Director of the Institute: Kaius Tuori
content:
Dr. Kaius Tuori has been appointed as the next Director of the Finnish Institute in Rome. He will begin his four-year term at Villa Lante in August 2026.

Tuori is a scholar of ancient history and Roman law, currently working as Professor of European Intellectual History at the University of Helsinki. He previously served as Director of the Centre of Excellence in Law, Identity and the European Narratives, funded by the Research Council of Finland (EuroStorie.org, 2018–2025). In addition, he holds the title of Docent in Legal History at the Faculty of Law, University of Helsinki.

His research is interdisciplinary, combining legal history, intellectual history, and ancient history with perspectives from the social sciences.</
creator: Nanni Hiltunen

title: 21.1.26 Lecture: Lived religion: Rituals and practices in later medieval canonization and inquisition processes
content:
Wednesday, January 21st, 2026, at 6:00 PM
Villa Lante al Gianicolo, Passeggiata del Gianicolo 10
Admission is free; seating subject to availability.

The lecture will be held in English.

Lived religion: Rituals and practices in later medieval canonization and inquisition processes

In the later medieval period, increasing levels of literacy and education, rapid urbanization, and an expanding economy led to the blooming of lay devotion through the emergence of new forms and modes of religiosity. At the same time, new mechanisms to investigate and control religiosity were developed, such as the canonization process of new saints and the inquisition process to fight heresy. content:

Villa Lante al Gianicolo, Passeggiata del Gianicolo 10

Ville e giardini di Roma. Una corona di delizie

Dott.ssa Alberta Campitelli

Il Museo di Roma-Palazzo Braschi, ospita fino al prossimo aprile, una grande esposizione dedicata al patrimonio di ville e giardini della città. È un’occasione per ripercorrerne la storia dal Cinquecento al Novecento, attraverso dipinti, modelli, incisioni e sculture, e comprendere quali e quante tipologie si sono susseguite nel tempo, seguendo il mutare del gusto e della moda, ma anche a causa di mutate condizioni politiche e sociali. title: Wihuri fellow 25-26 Maria Jokela
content:
The Institute’s Wihuri fellow for the year 2025-2026 is Maria Jokela, who is working on her doctoral thesis on the relationship between the Eastern and the Western Roman Empire and the prejudices that start to show up between them during Late Antiquity.

The purpose of Jokela’s research is to investigate how, in Late Antiquity, prejudices began to form between the Eastern and the Western Roman Empire and how these prejudices deepened over the centuries and ultimately led, during the Fourth Crusade, to the destruction and sack of the city of Constantinople by the Western troops. The research focuses particularly on the period between 300 and 800 CE, and its primary sources are Greek and Latin historiography.

Jokela’s research focuses on Late Antiquity
